title: Flu outbreak at Women’s and Children’s Hospital Adelaide
text:
Health authorities are scrambling to protect babies at the Women’s and Children’s Hospital from an influenza outbreak, putting four newborns with symptoms in isolation and dosing 30 newborns with powerful antiviral medicine.

The emergency over the weekend was followed by a lengthy power outage overnight which caused three pediatric surgeries to be postponed until today.

The hospital’s Department of Neonatal Medicine Unit Head, Dr Chad Andersen, said four babies have flu symptoms – all in the convalescent nursery.

“Two babies have tested positive for influenza A and a further two babies have developed influenza symptoms in one room of the neonatal nursery at the Women’s and Children’s Hospital,” he said.

“Babies in intensive care and high dependency have not been exposed to influenza as it has been detected and confined to the convalescent nursery.

"It mutates quite rapidly": What you need to know about this deadly flu season A doctor explains: How do you know if you have the flu, and when does it become deadly?

“All symptomatic babies have been isolated in closed cots and parents with babies in the neonatal nursery have been informed, including those recently discharged.”

Clinicians have commenced using the antiviral medicine Tamiflu for all babies in the convalescent nursery to cut the risk of cross infection and reduce illness severity in babies who are symptomatic.

Dr Andersen said the move is standard process as a precaution and was done with parental consent which was sought on Saturday.

He stressed Tamiflu is safe to use in babies, though can sometimes cause nausea and vomiting, while other side effects are rare. All babies are being closely monitored by medical and nursing staff.

There are currently 58 babies in the neonatal nursery, with approximately 30 of those in the convalescent nursery.

media_camera Two babies have tested positive for influenza A and a further two babies have developed influenza symptoms at the Women’s and Children’s Hospital. Picture: Getty Images

The use of Tamiflu follows international guidelines developed in outbreak conditions.

WCH officials say there is a very high vaccination rate among all staff.

In addition, all staff have been advised to stay home if sick and seek medical attention, as well as leave the hospital if they become unwell during the shift.

A blackout in parts of North Adelaide lasting from approximately 5.23pm to 8.50pm last night left a section of the WCH without mains power supplied by SA Power Networks.

“The hospital generator operated as planned and took effect immediately, supplying power to the essential areas of the hospital,” a hospital spokeswoman said.

“There was no clinical risk and there has been no adverse patient outcomes. As a precaution, some patients have been moved and some surgeries rescheduled until SA Power Networks can confirm their issue is rectified.”

A similar blackout hit the hospital last year.

Opposition health spokesman Chris Picton has renewed calls for an independent review of the hospital’s generator to ensure it is ready in the case of a prolonged blackout.
description: A flu outbreak at the Womens and Childrens Hospital has hit at least four newborns and triggered action including isolating babies and giving 30 infants powerful antiviral medicine.
